awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Structured Learning of Distribution Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
A rapid acceleration in both volume and complexity of public domain and scientific data presents new and exciting challenges. This project aims to develop a theoretical framework for structured learning of distribution spaces and study tools for identifying and utilizing probabilistic structure in high-dimensional large volume data. This project lies within the intersection of multiple disciplines: signal processing, pattern recognition, machine learning, probability and statistics, and thus will foster collaboration among these disciplines. The application of the proposed framework to data-driven medical diagnosis and ecological research will further the impact of this project beyond the realm of computational data analysis. Additionally, this research sets a goal to enrich the quality of education for both undergraduate and graduate students, through exciting integration of research, application, and new curriculum.

The research framework consists of geometrically-constrained probabilistic modeling and efficient optimization approaches for inference of multiple instance data. The project sets forth the following tasks i) confidence-constrained joint estimation of multiple discrete probability models, ii) joint learning of multiple distribution based geometrically-constrained maximum-entropy models, and iii) direct application of the developed framework to the analysis of clinical flow cytometry data for medical diagnosis and in-situ bioacoustics data for ecological research.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to develop a theoretical framework for learning to utilize probabilistic structure in high-dimensional large volume data. This project lies within the intersection of multiple disciplines: signal processing, pattern recognition, machine learning, probability and statistics to help foster collaboration among these disciplines as well as to enable further interdisciplinary research collaboration through application of the developed framework in various fields such as cancer diagnosis and ecology.

 
Intellectual Merit:  Through this project, we developed a collection of approaches for learning from data often characterized as multiple-instance data. Such data can be viewed as a collection of sets of data points. This format is important especially when data is vast but difficult to label. In this space, we focused on the development of algorithms considering both efficiency and accuracy. The algorithms developed have been adjusted and applied to real datasets.

Broader Impacts: This work was applied in different areas of application. Among such applications, we considered the use of the algorithms developed in bird bio-acoustics data analysis as well as in cancer diagnosis. For the first example, we applied the approach to assist with bird species recognition from in-situ audio recordings of bird species (collected through another project) to offer cutting edge performance when label information is limited. Similar concepts have been applied to assist in classification and annotation of histopathological images for presence or absence of different types of cancer. Moreover, the project helped to support graduate students in their research and engaged high-school students through the Apprenticeships in Science & Engineering (ASE) program of the Saturday Academy.


Last Modified: 09/08/2022
Modified by: Raviv Raich
